question: Question_01_(g)
statement:
Short-Answer Questions. Put your answer in the box provided but show
your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but not all questions
are of equal difficulty.

Find the area of the region bounded by the graph of
$\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{1}{(2x - 4)^{2}}$ and the $x$-axis between
$x = 0$ and $x = 1$.
sols:
We proceed directly using the hints. First, the area is given by

\begin{align*}\int_{0}^{1}\frac{1}{(2x-4)^{2}}dx\end{align*}

Using the substitution \emph{u = 2x-4} we find \emph{du = 2dx}. When
\emph{x = 0} we find \emph{u = -4}, when \emph{x = 1} we find \emph{u =
-2}. Hence

\begin{align*}
\int_{0}^{1}\frac{1}{(2x-4)^{2}}dx &= \int_{-4}^{-2}\frac1{u^2} \frac{du}2\\
&= \frac12 \int_{-4}^{-2}u^{-2}du \\
&= \frac12 \left.(-u^{-1})\right|_{-4}^{-2} \\
&= -\frac12 ((-2)^{-1}-(-4)^{-1}) \\
&= -\frac12 \left(-\frac12 + \frac14\right)\\
&= \frac18\end{align*}
hints:
The area between a curve and the \emph{x}-axis is just the integral from
the function on the region.
